text: Yeah, sure. Thanks, Dawn. A model like this at any point in time, it reflects current knowledge or recent knowledge around population and where jobs are, and it stores that information in cells, and there's two and a half thousand cells  containing that data across the whole Waikato region. And it also takes inputs from the Auckland transport model and the Bay of Plenty transport model and further south and feeds those onto the network. So at any point in time, it's got population data and jobs data and information that come from prior census.  And so it will never be fully up to date, but there is a process every year where current traffic count information is used to revalidate the model and to tune it to try and make it line up with current traffic volumes as much as possible.  But because it is a complex model and it covers the whole region, it does mean that that process is not being done every month or every six months. It's more a 12 month or an 18 month process to make those changes and validations. So as we say, it is a strategic model and it will  from the data make a reasonably good assessment of the number of trips that are occurring in an area, but it may not assign those trips completely accurately to the road network because it is a strategic model, not a fine grained model.  So we do, Councillor Gordon has definitely pointed out areas where that coarseness of the model shows up with inaccurate figures for individual roads. But at the current time, the WRTM is being updated with the census data with  growth projection data and future network data. So that's where future roads and intersections will be built on the network. So each of the seven local authorities involved will feed that data into the model. And then the model will be run again and tested and validated again later this year. So that updated model will be available for any future business case work we do.  And we can also use that model in a way where we take the trip data out of it and then we assign it manually to the network to get closer alignment. But there are other tools which Robert mentioned like Bluetooth tracking.  And in preparation for our work on the Victoria Bridge later this year, we have started some Bluetooth tooth tracking where there are sensors placed around Cambridge Now, which are operating that record the Bluetooth signal from vehicles that drive by and sees where they go. And that's all anonymized. Individual vehicles can't be identified or anything like that.  And that gives us a good idea, you know, traffic coming in on the main routes into Cambridge and within Cambridge, where are those trips to and from and what time of day, and that we'll be using that information to help us plan for the inevitable.  disruption that occurs when the Victoria Street Bridge has major work and we need to partially close it to traffic.
